definition: to glower (at sb)/to cast an angry look

sentences.english: She scowls at Josh, telling him to meet her in her lab at 0800 tomorrow.
sentences.chinese: 她怒視傑克，讓它明早八點在她的實驗室見她。

sentences.english: Julia scowled at her jeweled tortoise .
sentences.chinese: 這時朱莉婭怒視着那隻嵌着鑽石的烏龜。

sentences.english: The Brute looked about the bridge, blinked, and then glared at Fred.
sentences.chinese: 鬼面獸看着艦橋，眨着眼睛，然後怒視着弗雷德。

sentences.english: All morning I was dreading lunch, fearing his bizarre glares.
sentences.chinese: 整個早上我都在懼怕着午餐，害怕他異乎尋常的怒視。

sentences.english: "Year" towards mother-in-law home glower moment, then head over the past forward.
sentences.chinese: “年”朝婆婆家怒視片刻，隨即狂叫着撲過去。

sentences.english: I looked at the men and the women angrily.
sentences.chinese: 我回過頭去怒視着那一男一女。

sentences.english: The teacher scowled at the noisy boy.
sentences.chinese: 地怒視那個喧鬧的男孩。

sentences.english: Arachne stopped her spinning and looked at the old dame with anger in her countenance.
sentences.chinese: 阿拉喀涅停下了紡織，怒視着老婆婆。

sentences.english: The most glaring inequality is that between managers and the rest.
sentences.chinese: 怒視的不平等是那在經理和休息之間。

sentences.english: He glared at Bill, ready to teach him a lesson.
sentences.chinese: 他怒視着比爾，準備教訓他一頓。

sentences.english: Julia scowled at her jewelled tortoise .
sentences.chinese: 這時朱莉婭怒視着那隻嵌着鑽石的烏龜。

sentences.english: Why are you scowling at me?
sentences.chinese: 你爲什麼要瞪眼怒視我？

sentences.english: My kid brother got warm chuckles, I got perplexed glares.
sentences.chinese: 我弟弟他有溫暖的輕笑，我總有令人不解的怒視。

sentences.english: The whole class glared at the teacher when he told them their punishment.
sentences.chinese: 在老師向全班宣佈處罰時，全班同學氣憤地怒視着他。

sentences.english: I glare up at the family photos on the mantel, over the fireplace.
sentences.chinese: 我擡頭怒視壁爐架上的家庭照片，就在壁爐的上方。

sentences.english: He glared at me like a bull at a red rag.
sentences.chinese: 他像公牛怒視紅布一樣對我怒目而視。

definition: not to glance sideways (idiom)/to gaze fixedly/to be fully concentrated/to preserve a correct attitude
to whisper to one another's ear
see 驚慌失措|惊慌失措[jing1 huang1 shi1 cuo4]
to have a lifeless look in one's eyes (idiom)
Horse-Face, one of the two guardians of the underworld in Chinese mythology
to turn red (in the face)/to flush (with embarrassment or anger)
